column2: Olivia, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I HATE THIS DRUG!!!! I am Bipolar Type 1 and began taking Latuda. Latuda works great but I had minor agitation and restlessness on it so doc put me on Cogentin. I stopped taking it a day ago because it has caused me to have disorientation, confusion and short term memory loss. I have a memory like an elephant, normally. I'd rather be restless than be in a horrid cognitive state. I do not recommend this med. It has dumbed me down. I hope it's only temporary.

column1: Parkinsonism due to Degenerations in the Brain
column2: solarevol, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I started taking cogentin originally to balance out side effects of my anti-depressant. It really really helped a lot. I felt normal and had more energy than i had before. I had had a brain injury from smoking k2 and taking cogentin reversed a lot of my confusion and improved my memory.

column2: Ellatude, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Caregiver)
column9: My 17 year old daughter was put on this medication for dystonia.  She immediately began having violent mood swings as reported by another caregiver.  It does help with her involuntary movements, however the emotional side effects are as debilitating for her as the dystonia. She has extreme panic/anxiety, anger, despair, giddiness, all within the span of minutes to hours.  The more often she takes the medication, the more extreme the emotional reactions become. I hope this helps ohter people!

column2: Be of good cheer!, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I take Cogentin 1mg twice daily for relief from tremor(s). It has done more to improve the side effects of tremor than anything yet. I take other medications which can actually cause tremor. I prefer not to take an additivephysically and psychologically medication to combat tremor. Often times other medications are the culprit in ones regimen to treat a certain infirmity; check out the overall side effect possibility of each medication. Each medication has general side effects and the combination of all may likely produce side effects. "Different strokes for different folks" is generally the reality of taking medications as it also applies to other things in life! Have a great day!

column2: Be of good cheer!, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Each day I've noticed gradual improvement by taking Cogentin 1mg twice a day. I'm after ~ 10 days of Cogentin, and counting, already realizing a major difference in self confidence to actually try certain tasks of which I for some time avoided. I hope to improve even more concerning relief from  tremor. Have a great day!

column2: Been there too, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took cogentin a few years ago to counteract side effects from a neuroleptic (EPS).  Soon I was falling asleep all the time while driving, unable to speak in a complete sentence, and apparently raving about nonexistent missiles in Japan.  I can't even remember most of what happened during that period of time.  When I saw my doctor and couldn't communicate with him at all either by speaking or writing, he had to hospitalize me to get me stabilized and to change my medications.

column9: Mother was given this for involuntary tics and shaking due to something they do not know what. She started having severe confusion and halluciation after 1 day I had the stop it immediately. She is 88 and weighs only 95 lbs. Way to much for her.  Very dry mouth can hardly talk.

column2: Zeliris, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This drug was prescribed to me for treatment of side effects I had from Abilify, such as shakiness. It has worked very well, and I no longer have problems with side effects.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had a horrible Extrapyramidal reaction from taking the anti-nausea med compazine. Benadryl tabs taken at home were not enough, so I went into the ER. They gave me an IV with an additional 25MG of benadryl & cogentin. I felt completely better & my symptoms disappeared within 5 minutes. It was a life saver.

column2: brandon22, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have taken this medication for TD caused by Haldol. The side effects where extremely bad. I could not read, it made everything blury. My mouth was really dry. I think it made me more paraniod than when I was off all medications. I don't know but I think the cogentin also caused me to get something similar restless leg syndrome while I was on it because I couldn't quit moving my legs at bed time. Cogentin did unfreeze my body like it should. The medicine(for me) is good for emergencies like TD on occasion but I won't never take it regularly again.

column2: angelbre, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: my husband is taking it with the ability and it has messed him up. He has memory lose and can't remember what day or week it is. He can't even concentrate on what he is doing or saying. He also repeats hiself. He didn't do this until he started taking this med. I will def. look into trying to see if there is anything else he can take with the abilify.

column2: lacey, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: muscle spasms calmed down and then stopped for several hours.

What you should know about this medication. I have been shaking uncontrollably, and my teeth chatter all day.  I have constant tremor in my limbs and lower jaw.  My mouth is so dry that I have to use all Biotene products to keep my skin from sticking to my teeth, and my tongue is tremoring in my mouth all day.  I have a hard time talking and swallowing due to the tongue tremor and my mouth being so dry.  I am taking this medicine to help with EPS from perphenazine a.k.a. Trilafon.  The Cogentin gives me excessive confusion, dizzyness, and double vision along with blury vision.  My eyes are even dry. I have to keep putting drops in my eyes all day long.  I can't study for tests, read, or drive on this medication, and after I wake up in the morning, it takes me awhile to figure out where I am.  I also find myself randomly blurting out what I'm thinking without knowing what I am saying.  I just keep blurting out words while I have been on this medication rather uncontollably.  It's like this medication causes Terets.  Please be advised.  I don't think I will be on this medication much longer.

column2: 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)

column9: My stepdaughter is taking this medication, and if there is any other medication to replace this one, use it!  My stepdaughter has experienced severe confusion and memory loss. It has really made her brain fuzzy. I think she would be better off without this medication.
